<h2><a href="#homework-01-setup" aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" id="user-content-homework-01-setup"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a><strong>Homework 01 SETUP</strong></h2>
<ol>
<li>Create a Github repository for N741 Homework 1. Initialize it with a README file.</li>
<li>In RStudio, create a new project for N741 Homework 1.</li>
<li>Link RStudio to your Github repository for N741 homework 1.</li>
</ol>
<pre lang="{r"><code>knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
library(gapminder)
</code></pre>
<h2><a href="#gapminder-example" aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" id="user-content-gapminder-example"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Gapminder Example</h2>
<p>The following report is based on the R code examples at the <strong>Gapminder</strong> Github repository located at <a href="https://github.com/jennybc/gapminder">https://github.com/jennybc/gapminder</a>.</p>
<h2><a href="#gapminder-dataset---summary-statistics" aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" id="user-content-gapminder-dataset---summary-statistics"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Gapminder dataset - summary statistics</h2>
<p>The <code>gapminder</code> dataset which is built into the <code>gapminder</code> package, has 6 variables and 1704 observations. We can list the variables in the dataset, using the <code>names()</code> function.</p>
<h3><a href="#variables-columns-in-gapminder-dataset" aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" id="user-content-variables-columns-in-gapminder-dataset"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Variables (columns) in gapminder dataset</h3>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>names(gapminder)
</code></pre>
<h3><a href="#structure-of-the-gapminder-dataset" aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" id="user-content-structure-of-the-gapminder-dataset"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Structure of the gapminder dataset</h3>
<p>Another way to see the "structure" of the dataset is to run the <code>str()</code> function.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>str(gapminder)
</code></pre>
<p>You'll notice that the 1st 2 columns/variables "country" and "continent" are both "Factor" type variables. Variables 3 and 5 "year" and "pop" are both "int" Integer type variables. Variables 4 and 6 "lifeExp" and "gdpPercap" are both "num" Numeric type variables.</p>
<h3><a href="#summary-statistics-of-the-gapminder-dataset" aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" id="user-content-summary-statistics-of-the-gapminder-dataset"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Summary Statistics of the gapminder dataset</h3>
<p>The built in function <code>summary()</code> in base R does a good simple summary statistics for all variables in the dataset provided. Since this dataset only has 6 variable, we can simply call <code>summary(gapminder)</code> which will give us the summary statistics for all 6 variables.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>summary(gapminder)
</code></pre>
<h3><a href="#run-specific-statistic-for-a-given-variable" aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" id="user-content-run-specific-statistic-for-a-given-variable"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Run specific statistic for a given variable</h3>
<p>Suppose we only wanted to get the <em>mean</em> life expectancy. To do this we can use the built-in function <code>mean()</code>. To select only the "lifeExp" variable, we can either refer to it by which column it is in the dataset using <code>gapminder[,4]</code> which says to select all rows by leaving the 1st element between the <code>[]</code> before the comma blank and putting a 4 after the comman which specifies the 4th column. Another way to select a column is to use the name of that column which is "lifeExp" and use the dollar sign <code>$</code> selector to get <code>gapminder$lifeExp</code>.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>mean(gapminder$lifeExp)
</code></pre>
<h3><a href="#in-line-code" aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" id="user-content-in-line-code"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>In line code</h3>
<p>We can use the same command above, but call it "inline" instead of as a separate code chunk which sets the output apart from the text in a separate section of the report. If you simply want the computation executed and the result inserted into the body of text you are writing you use "inline" code. To do this you use the following syntax <em>r mean(gapminder$lifeExp)</em> between the backtick marks <code></code>. Using this syntax, we can write the following sentence.</p>
<p>The mean life expectancy is <code>r mean(gapminder$lifeExp)</code> years.</p>
<p>We can clean this up further by wrapping this command within the <code>round()</code> function and specifying the number of digits we want reported for this numeric result. This time, use the following command inline <em>r round(mean(gapminder$lifeExp), digits=2)</em> and we'll rewrite the sentence below.</p>
<p>The mean life expectancy is <code>r round(mean(gapminder$lifeExp), digits=2)</code> years.</p>
<h3><a href="#homework-01-exercise---task-1" aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" id="user-content-homework-01-exercise---task-1"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a><strong>Homework 01 Exercise - Task 1</strong></h3>
<p>Modify the sentence above to also provide the standard deviation, median and sample size for life expectancy, set <code>digits=2</code>.</p>
<p>Hint: Read help pages for the functions <code>sd()</code>, <code>median()</code>, and <code>length()</code>.</p>
<h3><a href="#look-at-a-statistic-by-continent" aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" id="user-content-look-at-a-statistic-by-continent"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Look at a statistic by continent</h3>
<p>Using the 1st code example at the <code>gapminder</code> Github repository at <a href="https://github.com/jennybc/gapminder">https://github.com/jennybc/gapminder</a>, use the <code>aggregate()</code> command to see the median life expectancy by continent. You'll notice that the 1st variable listed is the "lifeExp" variable we want run "by" "continent". The "by" is indicated using the <em>tilde</em> symbol <code>~</code>. The 2nd variable listed is "continent" - this 2nd variable is usually a "factor-type" variable or group variable. <em>Hint: Try running lifeExp by year to get median lifeExp for each year.</em></p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>aggregate(lifeExp ~ continent, gapminder, median)
</code></pre>
<h3><a href="#homework-01-exercise---task-2" aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" id="user-content-homework-01-exercise---task-2"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a><strong>Homework 01 Exercise - Task 2</strong></h3>
<p>Modify the r code chunk above to also provide the mean and standard deviation for life expectancy by continent.</p>
<h3><a href="#plot-life-expectancy-by-continent" aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" id="user-content-plot-life-expectancy-by-continent"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Plot Life Expectancy by Continent</h3>
<p>For the following plot, we will use the <code>ggplot2</code> package. Please be sure to install the package if you haven't already. Go to RStudio "Tools" menu and select "Install Packages" and type in "ggplot2". The R code chunk below will load the <code>ggplot2</code> package using the <code>library(ggplot2)</code> command. For now, we are using the code provided at the <strong>Gapminder</strong> Github repository located at <a href="https://github.com/jennybc/gapminder">https://github.com/jennybc/gapminder</a>. We will explore and explain the ggplot syntax in further detail later this semester. For now, notice that in the <code>aes()</code> section of code below, there are 2 "aesthetics" provided to <code>ggplot()</code> - namely that <code>x = continent</code> and <code>y = lifeExp</code>. The code below generates 2 plots overlaid on top of each other. The 1st is a boxplot generated by <code>geom_boxplot</code> and then a 2nd plot of "jittered" points is overlaid using the <code>geom_jitter()</code> command.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>library(ggplot2)
ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = continent, y = lifeExp)) +
  geom_boxplot(outlier.colour = "hotpink") +
  geom_jitter(position = position_jitter(width = 0.1, height = 0), alpha = 1/4)
</code></pre>
<h3><a href="#homework-01-exercise---task-3" aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" id="user-content-homework-01-exercise---task-3"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a><strong>Homework 01 Exercise - Task 3</strong></h3>
<p>Modify the R code chunk above to now produce two more plots: one for <code>gdpPercap</code> instead of <code>lifeExp</code> and one for <code>pop</code> instead of <code>lifeExp</code>. <em>Hint: change out the variable for <code>y</code> above. You will need the entire code chunk run twice - once for each different plot.</em></p>
<h3><a href="#selecting-a-data-subset-and-customizing-plot-colors" aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" id="user-content-selecting-a-data-subset-and-customizing-plot-colors"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Selecting a Data subset and Customizing Plot Colors</h3>
<p>For this next example, we will use the built-in "country_colors" dataset defined in the <code>gapminder</code> package to create an updated data frame (cope of the <code>gapminder</code> dataset) called <code>gap_with_colors</code>. <em>NOTE: To see the built-in datasets in the <code>gapminder</code> package, type <code>data(package = "gapminder")</code> in the console.</em> After setting up the custom colors, the next line of R code defines which continents we plan to "keep" in our plot. This defines and object called <code>keepers</code> below. In this case, we are "keeping" Africa and Europe and the year 2007. So, we are subsetting the dataset for 2 countries and 1 year. Then the <code>plot()</code> command creates the scatterplot of life expectancy by GDP per capita with a dot representing each county within 2 continents (Africa and Europe) for only 2007. The size of each dot is represents a 3rd variable "pop" for population size.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code># for convenience, integrate the country colors into the data.frame
gap_with_colors &lt;-
  data.frame(gapminder,
             cc = I(country_colors[match(gapminder$country,
                                         names(country_colors))]))

# bubble plot, focus just on Africa and Europe in 2007
keepers &lt;- with(gap_with_colors,
                continent %in% c("Africa", "Europe") &amp; year == 2007)
plot(lifeExp ~ gdpPercap, gap_with_colors,
     subset = keepers, log = "x", pch = 21,
     cex = sqrt(gap_with_colors$pop[keepers]/pi)/1500,
     bg = gap_with_colors$cc[keepers])
</code></pre>
